profile_data.summary:
I am a Ph.D. candidate in Computer Science working on Human-centered AI and Responsible AI in conversational agents. I have four years of experience in leading human-AI interaction research on conversational agents and large language model fine tuning (Python, R, GPT). I have published my work at ACM CSCW and my latest full track paper has won the best paper award at ACM CUI 2024. During my internship at Idaho National Laboratory, I developed and evaluated an explainable AI interface for water plant operators. 

I am seeking full-time opportunities in Research Scientist or Postdoctoral positions involving Responsible AI, Human-centered AI, or Machine Learning applications in Privacy Enhancing Technologies.
profile_data.headline: Seeking Full-time opportunities | Responsible AI and Human-Centered AI researcher | Former Idaho National Lab intern | Ph.D. Candidate at Indiana University

experience.description:
Responsibilities:

◆ Define Project Scope: Systematically reviewed existing literature to identify usability and trustworthiness gaps in current Voice Assistant designs and define project scopes.
◆ Develop Experimental Designs: Created robust experimental designs tailored to the unique requirements of each project, aligning them with the research scope.
◆ Conduct Usability Studies: Designed prototypes and conduct quantitative and qualitative studies to elucidate user perceptions of proposed Voice Assistant designs.
◆ Perform Data Analysis: Performed thorough data analyses to derive meaningful insights and draw conclusions from experiments.
◆ Interpret and Present Findings of Studies: Frequent presentation of findings to the research team to gather additional insights from diverse perspectives.
◆ Collaborate on Research Efforts: Utilized periodic feedback from the research group to continuously improve conceptual and experimental designs, ensuring the highest quality of research outcomes for Voice Assistant designs.
◆ Manuscript Development: Led the writing and refinement of manuscripts for publication, synthesizing complex research findings into coherent narratives, and adapting content based on constructive feedback from the research group.
experience.title: Graduate Research Assistant

experience.description:
Worked on  Machine learning and eXplainable AI (XAI) with a focus on improving User Interface reliability and trust for skilled operators.

Responsibilities:

• Formulated an Execution Plan for an Explainable AI Project: Devised a comprehensive plan for implementing Explainable AI within a water pump fault prediction software. This included strategically enhancing Explainable AI techniques to improve the interpretability of machine learning predictions.

• Collaborated on Interface Design with the Human Factor Team: Worked closely with the human factor team to create questionnaires for experts and operators. The goal was to uncover their requirements for interface design, ensuring clarity in understanding machine learning prediction outcomes.

• Facilitated Iterative Development of Explainable AI Interface: Through multiple planning and development cycles, incorporating feedback from mentors, I successfully crafted an efficient Explainable AI interface for the water pump fault prediction software with LIME and SHAP. This interface not only enhanced the interpretability of machine learning outcomes but also empowered operators to make well-informed decisions.
experience.title: Python Programmer

publications.name: The Impact of Perceived Tone, Age, and Gender on Voice Assistant Persuasiveness in the Context of Product Recommendations
publications.publisher: ACM Conference on Conversational User Interfaces
publications.description: We investigated how the perceived tone, age, and gender of voice assistants' (VAs) voices persuade users in online shopping contexts. We found that VAs with positive or neutral tones and those with middle-aged male or younger female voices significantly increased participants' likelihood of following product recommendations. We demonstrate the importance of customizing VA voices to enhance user comfort and engagement while emphasizing ethical considerations to protect against manipulation.

publications.name: Decaying Photos for Enhanced Privacy: User Perceptions Towards Temporal Redactions and ‘Trusted’ Platforms
publications.publisher: Proceedings of the ACM on Human-Computer Interaction, Volume 6, Issue CSCW2
publications.description: In this paper, we have proposed two temporal redaction methods while posting photos in the social media to enhance user privacy. These methods involve sensitive contents of a posted photo being decayed gradually over time so that the contents are not identifiable after a certain period. We have also compared users’ sharing behavior for these methods to the existing sharing methods such as sharing without any redaction or ephemeral (delayed deletion) sharing.

member.occupation: Seeking Full-time opportunities | Responsible AI and Human-Centered AI researcher | Former Idaho National Lab intern | Ph.D. Candidate at Indiana University

projects.description:
We evaluated the persuasiveness of conversational agents' (CAs) vocal tones on users in online shopping, focusing on positive, negative, and neutral tones. Users preferred either positive or neutral tones by the CAs and expected the tone to be customized based on the task and context. This paper won the 𝗯𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗽𝗮𝗽𝗲𝗿 𝗮𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗱 in ACM CUI 2024.

Methods: Voice Synthesis, Quantitative analysis, Qualitative Analysis, Interactive user study design

Tools: Python, R, Microsoft Speech Studio, Qualtrics
projects.title: Evaluating the Persuasiveness of Conversational Agents' Vocal Tone

member.occupation: Seeking Full-time opportunities | Responsible AI and Human-Centered AI researcher | Former Idaho National Lab intern | Ph.D. Candidate at Indiana University

projects.description: Led an experimental study showing that user acceptance of AI decisions depends on personality traits and technology comfort. Findings suggest that explainable AI (XAI) designs should tailor explanations, potentially omitting them for users with high neuroticism and low tech comfort, to improve collaboration. This work was accepted and presented in ACM CHI 2024 Workshop on Human-Centered Explainable AI (HCXAI).
projects.title: Personality and Explainability: How Detailed Explanations Impact Agreement with XAI

member.occupation: Seeking Full-time opportunities | Responsible AI and Human-Centered AI researcher | Former Idaho National Lab intern | Ph.D. Candidate at Indiana University

projects.description:
🔍 Improving Machine Learning interpretability of Operator Software: I implemented Explainable AI in an operator-based predictive maintenance system of a power plant, where I enhanced an interface to visualize important components of the system that influence the machine learning model outcomes. This work will help bridge the gaps between black-box machine learning models and human operators and make AI more trustworthy to operators in similar contexts.

📈 Increasing Situational Awareness: I integrated operator logs with the status graphs of power plant components. By connecting the historical logs with the machine status, we've created a comprehensive snapshot of the system's health along with past insights. Operators are now empowered with a clearer understanding of the system component status, which is a game-changer for quick decision-making.

In addition, I worked on designing warning insights for special scenarios that require human attention in an automated control system as a part of power plants. Imagine if your automated car could predict when there might be an obstacle in front and give you a heads-up. That's essentially what we did for the automation control system. These insights alert operators about potential issues before they escalate and provide suitable alternatives, improving overall system reliability.
projects.title: Explainable AI (XAI) in Power Plant Fault Prediction

projects.description:
Led a team of developers to develop the android counterpart of a Software as a Solution (SaaS) system for Sales distribution monitoring in Bangladesh. The android application involved a framework with the following
• Dynamic UI builder library for customized mobile application 
• Data sync library to ensure data integrity in offline data synchronization 
• Survey Builder library to dynamically facilitate varying survey questions in the mobile app
projects.title: SaaS solution for Sales Distribution Monitoring (Mobile App)

member.occupation: Seeking Full-time opportunities | Responsible AI and Human-Centered AI researcher | Former Idaho National Lab intern | Ph.D. Candidate at Indiana University

projects.description: Developed the android counterpart of the Agricultural Traceability system by Field Buzz. We used Realm, Retrofit, and Volley for the application development. The data synchronization was designed in such a way that remote farmers from Uganda, Kenya or Brazil could use the application with any internet connection and their offline data would automatically sync with the server once they are connected to the network.
projects.title: Agricultural Traceability (Mobile App)
